Posts.Content: Thanks for sharing such wonderful news! My husband is having his first chemo infusion (Cisplatin) and radiation treatment in a few hours.  It's SO good to hear your news! We have a miserable, painful, debilitating road to go down, but we've been told, and believe, there is no other medical choice. The people on these boards are absolutely wonderful. They, like you, have been encouraging, loving, compassionate, and very importantly, truthful. I, as my dear husband's caregiver, have a tendency to sink to the depths of despair and worry....but then I read a post like yours. Thanks so much! diane
Posts.Title: Good news we should all be able to get.

Posts.Content: Thanks for bringing up this subject, Katrina, and all the comments made. No one has offered their age when discussing Chemo-Brain. I'm Caretaker/Wife to my Husband Bart, who's been fighting H&N Cancer since 9/09 dx. Obviously, as Caretaker I have no legitimate claim to the term "Chemo-Brain," but I've adopted it anyway. It's easier to pronounce than Alzheimers, and supposedly can be temporary. At 66, I've been experiencing all of the symptoms people have related, some for many years. Despite too many hours to count of Brain Games and Suduko, I still forget names. What used to be a sometimes thing when I was younger, is now nearly ALL the time. I usually meet this one head on by introducing myself, then stating, "I know I know you, but have forgotten your name." I started Substitute Teaching 10 years ago to keep my brain active and growing, which it has to a certain degree. But my students, mostly Middle Schoolers, are always "filling in the blanks" when I can't think of a word. They often ask me if I remember their names and I tell them truthfully, "No, which puts you in a very desirable category. It's the trouble makers I remember!" That's a half-truth ~ I don't remember the names of the trouble makers either. And that's undoubtedly a gift ~ and why I'm continuing to do something I dearly love ~ teach! Thought I'd share a story you may have missed that was posted by Damon, our oft-times comic and brain cancer survivor: BAD NEWS AND WORSE NEWS From Robin Gosnall  This friend of mine had felt unwell for months, so he decided to see his doctor. The doctor examined him and referred him to the hospital to see various specialists. After a couple of weeks, all the test results came through, so my friend returned to see his doctor. "I'm very sorry", said the doctor. "I'm afraid I have bad news and worse news." "Tell me the worst." "I'll be honest, you have cancer, you'll be dead in three months." "Shite! " said my friend. "What on earth is the bad news?" "You also have Alzheimer's Disease." "Alzheimer's? Oh well, at least I don't have cancer."   TGIF Damon Nov 07 DX and??????? I forgot half a brain Have a great chuckle and laugh through the tough stuff, diane

Posts.Title: Chemo Brain

Posts.Content: My sister was just diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of left breast, very small, only 1 cm. MRI showed 3 more areas of concern. Surgeon suggested lumpectomy with 3 biopsies before. The biopsy showed her2 positive, estrogen pos.  She doesn't want to go through 3 more biopsies (first one was painful), and is leaning toward mastectomy decision. Right breast doesn't show anything.  Any ideas from some who've been there? Thanks in advance. diane T
Posts.Title: invasive ductal carcinoma, 3 more suspicious areas

Posts.Content: People with the same dx,.HELP! My sis has had MS since she was 18, is now 60 and has been diagnosed with breast cancer metastacized to the bones. She had attributed her back pain and everything else to the MS. Was taken to the hospital when pain got unbearable, which we later found was because there were two fractures in a bone in her back. Breast ca was discovered, a biopsy taken (we're waiting for results). She's on heavy pain meds. HELP, please!
Posts.Title: Sis dx "Breast cancer with mets to bones."

Posts.Content: It turned out, after both a needle and surgical biopsy, that she doesn't have breast cancer after all. Now one oncologist wanted to check some apparent lung nodules for ca, but was over-ridden, Thank God, by the surgeon, who then took a biopsy of her cancerous hip. We don't have the results yet.  She didn't bother with mammograms, smoked big time but gave it up when cigarettes became so costly. She's back to smoking now. Your reply is extremely encouraging! We just thought she was a goner, which is what she believes also. She's home now, on heavy meds for pain, but is awake much of the time. She's supposed to have a PET scan, but the hospital she was at didn't have a PET scanner. She's got doc appointments Fri, so we'll know more then. How did you get rid of the soft tumors, BTW, what are soft tumors anyway. What is DMSO? Thanks for your thoughts and prayers. You've given us hope.
Posts.Title: Sis dx "Breast cancer with mets to bones."

Posts.Content: Another of my sisters (Alice) who had a mastectomy has now been diagnosed with Malignant fibrous histiocytoma (soft tissue sarcoma) What I've looked up leads me to believe that's bone cancer. That's not soft tissue, is it? Would this Kelmun Protocol work? Docs say only option is surgery since it's caused by radiation and no good chemo for it.
Posts.Title: Sis dx "Breast cancer with mets to bones."

Posts.Content: I'm REALLY looking forward to looking at the resources you have ~ thanks! Thanks for replying also. Lois, my sis with both cancer & MS feels that the cancer is so widespread, that her only option is to finish the radiation (4 more treatments) to try to stop the pain. Her PET showed lung cancer already, but she doesn't cough, so the docs disbelieve the PET. Problem is, I don't believe she has the best docs, but she can't afford to go anywhere else. Alice, the breast cancer survivor had a "good news PET" The cancer hasn't spread, so all she needs is surgery. She's fighting with her insurance co. about going to MD Andersen for the surgery.
Posts.Title: Sis dx "Breast cancer with mets to bones."
